dialogues.text: A mom and pop bookstore.  Three isles wide.  MR. AND MRS. NATHAN, a couple in their early seventies, sit behind the counter and watch a black and white TV.  The PICTURE ON T

dialogues.speaker: SURROUND A CIRCLE.
dialogues.text: Morgan steps up to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extraterrestrials?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they keep alluding to.  It's just a bunch of crock.  They're trying to sell sodas, plain and simple.  I've been watching these reports since morning.  I've seen twelve soda commercials so far.  Twelve!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have book on extraterrestrials?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you believe this horse manure? Morgan shrugs.  Mrs. Nathan pushes her husband aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I think we have one.  Came by mistake in a shipment.  Decided to keep it for city people. Mrs. Nathan points over to the far corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last row.  Third book from the left honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham waits at a white counter.  A gum chewing PHARMACIS her early twenties, who looks like she's in her teens, glances through back shelves of medicines as she listens the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is no one saying the obvious?  This is just a rash case of copycats.  Someone, somewhere, does the first one.  It's on TV, it's on the internet.  In less than an hour a couple hundred people get the same brilliant idea and here we are... on the verge of mass hysteria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was asthma medicine right Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Morgan Hess.  And it's not Father anymore. The Pharmacist looks back at Graham and then reaches up a TURNS OFF THE RADIO.  She quietly finds the prescription the shelf and moves to the counter across from Graham. She doesn't ring it up.  She just stands there fiddling w the bag holding Morgan's medicine.  Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a favor Father? Graham stares at the girl.  Beat.  He nods "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I take confession with you? Beat.  Graham leans forward on the counter and takes the girl's hands in his.  He talks very slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracey, I -- am -- not -- a -- reverend -- anymore.  I haven't been for six months.  You know this. Beat.  When Tracey speaks her VOICE IS A BIT SHAKY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this stuff on TV... (beat) Joe Gills was in here talking about the end of the world... I'm just a little scared. (beat) Please.  I need to take confession with you. Graham looks at the young girl's teary eyes.  He exhales slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merrill stares up at a poster with a muscular guy in an A uniform standing at attention on a beach. We are in a narrow ARMY RECRUITING CENTER.  Inside the sm storefront space is a desk.  A gentleman sporting a CREWC sits behind it. A young man, Merrill's age, sits at a side card table fil out some forms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it figured. Merrill realizes the crewcut guy is talking to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had two separate folks tell me they think there are strangers around these parts the last couple of nights.  Can't tell what they look like, cause they're staying in the shadows -- covert like.  No one's got hurt mind you... And that's the give away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't see) I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called probing.  It's a military procedure.  You send a reconnaissance group, very small, to check out things.  Not to engage, but to evaluate the situation.  Evaluate the level of danger.  Make sure things are all clear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear for what? The crewcut guy savors the beat of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... For the rest of them. It takes a second, but Merrill smiles.  The crewcut guy smiles back.  Merrill points at a poster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a pamphlet or something I can read? The crewcut guy reaches to a stack of brochures.  Picks t top brochure and hands it to Merrill. The crewcut guy begins to stare at Merrill closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey you didn't used to play baseball did you? Merrill looks up from the brochure.  Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.  I know you.  You're Merrill Hess.  I was there that day you hit that five hundred and eighty seven footer over the left field wall and set the record.  That thing had a motor on it... It's still the record right? Merrill not, "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) I got the bat at home... On the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got two minor league home run records don't you? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five.  The five longest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, why aren't you in the pros making stacks of cash and getting handfuls of T and A?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause he also has the minor league strike out record. Merrill turns to the young man, about his age, who sits a the folding table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Lionel. LIONEL smirks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd just swing as hard as he could every time.  It didn't matter what the coach said, didn't matter who was on base, he'd whip that bat through the air as hard as he could... Looked like a lumber jack chopping down a tree. (beat) Merrill here, struck out more times than any two players. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really hold the strike out record? Beat.  Merrill tucks the pamphlet in his jacket.  Looks l he's not going to say anything.  When he does, the words soft and worn; they've been said a hundred times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt wrong not to swing. Beat.  The crewcut guy shakes his head.  Merrill turns an starts walking. As he passes Lionel, Merrill makes a small, quick move in Lionel's direction, like he might hit him.  Lionel flinch and covers his face. Merrill walks out the door of the army recruiting office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cursed thirty-seven times last week... I said the f-word a couple times, but mostly "shits" and "bastards." (beat) Is "Douche bag" a curse? Graham glances at the girl as she sits sideways to him at counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose it's in its usage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about "John you're a douche bag for kissing Barbara?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a curse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's not thirty-seven.  It's seventy-one. Graham's eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stole a bottle of Ruby red lip stick from K-mart... I punched my brother in the back three times... Graham looks around the empty store for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bo sits at a tiny reading table and drinks a glass of wat There is another glass, half-full, on her table.  Mrs. Na watches as the little girl takes careful sips. Beat.  Bo looks up with a grimace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's contaminated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl, there's something wrong with our water! Morgan doesn't look up from the extraterrestrial book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your water is fine.  Bo has a thing about her drinking water.  She's had it her whole life.  Like a tick people have.  Except it's not a tick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fascinated) Is that right? Bo shrugs.  She places the glass she sipped on the table the other glass. Mrs. Nathan stares at the four-year old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirteen! Everyone turns to the front of the store where Mr. Nathan points to the TV screen.  A Coke Cola commercial is on. Beat.  Mrs. Nathan turns back to find Morgan holding out extraterrestrial book to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merrill, Morgan and Bo are waiting in the parked car.  Be The driver's side opens and Graham sits in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pharmacy crowded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want any one of you spending time with Tracey Abernathy alone.  Is that understood? Beat.  Everyone nods, "yes." Graham puts the key in the ignition and turns the car on. Merrill watches as Graham's hand goes to put the car in reverse -- and then stops. Graham is staring out the windshield.  Merrill follows hi stare to a thin, thirty-year old man in a LEATHER JACKET coming out of a store.  Merrill's face changes expression too.  They both stare as the man passes in front of the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) Is that him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) Yeah. Everyone in the car watches the man in the leather jacket he steps off the sidewalk towards the truck.  It's here t he notices the stares.  He glances up to see the faces watching him from the station wagon. The leather jacketed man keeps moving to his truck.  He g in, turns it on, and without looking over to the station wagon, backs out of the parking lot. Beat.  The Hess family sits quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he? Nobody says anything for the longest time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the man who killed mom. Graham puts the station wagon in reverse and backs out in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SKY IS GOLDEN RED.  The crops sway hypnotically in a gentle breeze. The Hess station wagon pulls into their driveway.  It com to a stop in front of the house.  The engine goes off.  N one gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All four sit quietly not getting out. A MUFFLED SPIKE OF NOISE IS HEARD FROM THE BACK SEAT. Graham and Merrill turn and see Morgan pull the baby moni out of his jacket.  He holds it in his lap. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if Bo's baby monitor is picking up signals from the extraterrestrials? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this crop stuff.  They did it twenty-five years ago.  It was a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just static Morgan.  Turn it up and see. Morgan turns a knob on the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a code.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see that please. Morgan hands Graham the monitor in the front seat.  THE B COME AND GO AS THEY GET COVERED BY THE STATIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's broken Morgan.  It'll just keep doing this. (beat) Let's get out of the car okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might lose the signal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't just sit in the car in our own driveway like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll look like mental patients. Beat.  Nobody gets out of the station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting out now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do it. Graham pulls the handle.  His door opens.  He waits befor getting out.  The other three station wagon doors open ri after.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE CAR
dialogues.text: Graham stands and closes his driver side door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody move! Everyone becomes frozen, standing next to the station wag Three of the doors are open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voices.  Did you hear that? Everyone stares at the baby monitor in Graham's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not English though.  You heard the voices right Uncle Merrill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard them Morgan. Graham doesn't move his arm.  He keeps it out in the air where he had it as he closed his door.  Graham looks to Merrill over the roof of the station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably picking up another baby monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see it. Beat.  Graham moves.  He hands the monitor over the hood. Merrill reaches for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! Graham and Merrill freeze -- both touching the monitor ov the roof of the station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't sound like words. Merrill concentrates on THE SWIRLING MOVING TEXTURE COMIN FROM THE BABY MONITOR. Graham looks around at his rapt family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See this is why we're not watching those news reports.  People get obsessed. (beat) I'm letting go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll lose the signal! Graham looks at Merrill, who's now one of them.  Beat. Morgan is the first one to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let go. He moves from the back passenger door to the back bumper where he begins to climb onto the station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gets clearer, the higher you hold it. Morgan crawls on the roof and takes the monitor ever-so gently out of Graham and Merrill's outstretched hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgan, be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got him. Merrill climbs up over the side and joins Morgan on the r Merrill keeps a hand on his nephew.  Morgan raises the monitor above his head. THE RED LIGHTS ON THE BABY MONITOR ALL TURN ON.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDER.
dialogues.text: Bo runs to the front bumper and climbs onto the hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. Graham cuts her off by taking a seat on the hood.  He tak hold of Bo.  All four are on the car now. Morgan stands up on the roof of the station wagon.  Merri holds him by the waist. Bo tries to get up onto the roof by climbing over Graham the windshield.  Graham boosts her up over his head with hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merrill you got her. Merrill reaches out his free hand.  Bo reaches out to him THE SOUND FROM THE MONITOR SUDDENLY CHANGES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! Everyone STOPS exactly where they are.  Graham holds Bo o his head.  Bo reaches out to Merrill.  Merrill sits on th roof with one arm out.  Morgan stands with the baby monit raised high in the air.  The Hess family remains very sti on the hood of their station wagon as they listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) There's two of them talking.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER SEQUENCE LIKE A CONVERSATION.
dialogues.text: Graham struggles to hold Bo up.  Bo struggles to keep her arms out.  Merrill struggles not to turn his face to the incredible SOUNDS ABOVE HIS HEAD. THE TONES ESCALATE IN VOLUME. Morgan's eyes widen as THE SEQUENCE OF SOUNDS BECOMES SHO

dialogues.speaker: VIOLENT AND THEN WE HEAR A CLICK AND THEY'RE GONE.
dialogues.text: Beat.  Everyone looks up at the baby monitor.  The red li are off.  ONLY THE BLAND HUM OF NORMAL STATIC COMES FROM SPEAKER. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) They hung up. Graham brings Bo down into his lap.  Morgan takes a seat to Merrill on the roof.  The Hess family sits like mental patients on the top of their station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: WE ARE AT THE EDGE OF THE CROPS LOOKING BACK AT THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The LIGHTS are on in the kitchen.  We see Graham, Merrill the children doing dishes after dinner. The DOG IS BARKING FURIOUSLY.

dialogues.speaker: OUR VIEW TURNS TO LOOK AT THE BARN THROUGH THE CROPS.
dialogues.text: Isabelle, the remaining German Shepherd is tied to a post outside the barn.  The dog whips back and forth frantical She keeps looking in our direction.

dialogues.speaker: WE HEAR A SCREEN DOOR OPEN. WE TURN TO LOOK BACK AT THE
dialogues.text: HOUSE.  Graham steps out the back screen door with a bowl dog food and a bowl of water. We watch him as he walks towards the frantic dog.  When h gets close, Graham slows.  He approaches the dog carefull He places the two bowls close but not too close.  The dog no interest in them.  She keeps barking and glaring in ou direction. Graham watches her for a few moments, and THEN TURNS AND LOOKS DIRECTLY AT US FROM ACROSS THE YARD. WE PULL BACK INTO THE DARKNESS OF THE CROPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham stands frozen looking across his yard.  Isabelle, dog turns in desperate circles behind him.  Graham's eyes stay focused on the same point in the darkness.  He talks no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something?  Even entertaining the possibility of this for a minute has been exciting. Beat.  Graham starts to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see how people can get carried away with this type of thing. Graham reaches the barbecue area.  There's a flashlight o the picnic table.  Graham TURNS THE FLASHLIGHT ON.  A NAR BEAM FALLS ON THE GRASS FIVE FEET AHEAD OF HIM. Graham starts toward the crops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a kind of faith.  It's an intoxicating thing to believe in something you can't see.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAM OF LIGHT FALLS ON THE WALL OF CORN CROPS LINING
dialogues.text: BACKYARD.  Graham steps right up to them.  He hesitates a then steps into the field of CORN CROPS. We can't see two feet in any direction.  Six foot stalks corn line Graham on all sides.  THE FLASHLIGHT THROWS A WAVERING BEAM ON THE CROPS AHEAD OF HIM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were always good at that... THE BEAM OF HIS FLASHLIGHT FINDS A NARROW PATH.  Graham starts following it.  His shoulders brush crops on either side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believing in things you couldn't see. (beat) You would have been the first person on that station wagon wouldn't you?  You and Morgan would have been wrestling for that baby monitor. SOMETHING MOVES UP AHEAD. Graham stops.  HE SHINES HIS LIGHT DOWN THE PATH.  Nothin but crops disappearing into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be secretly kind of sad for everybody, when this turns out to be -- all just make believe. THERE'S MOVEMENT RIGHT NEXT TO HIM.  Graham spins and aim the FLASHLIGHT AT THE CROPS TO HIS RIGHT.  THE LIGHT ONLY PENETRATES A FEW FEET INTO THE CROPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) You're wasting your time here!  I'm not going to report this or anything you do to me crops, to the news or TV or anybody!  You're not going to get famous! Beat.  There is no response.  GRAHAM CAN HEAR HIS OWN

dialogues.speaker: HIM.
dialogues.text: Beat.  Graham holds his breath.  THE SOUND OF SOMEONE ELS BREATHING CONTINUES BEHIND HIM. Graham turns and drops the FLASHLIGHT at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: FAST AND LOUD NOW.
dialogues.text: Graham kneels down and gropes in the darkness.  His hands search over the ground in all directions.  They finally t the flashlight.  Graham quickly fumbles with it to find t "on" button.  He does.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE STANDS FIVE FEET AWAY.
dialogues.text: It instantly moves into the darkness.  Graham tries to ge up.  He stumbles backwards into the crops.  He's tangled crops as he struggles to rise.  He gets up and starts running. Leaves and stalks slap him from all directions.  He panic He doesn't know where he is.  THERE IS SOMETHING COMING BEHIND HIM. Graham makes a sudden right turn.  He puts his hands in f of him to protect his face and eyes.  He's running as fas he can.  HE HEARS STALKS OF CORN BREAKING BEHIND HIM. Another sudden turn, this time left.  Graham emerges into BACKYARD. Graham keeps running across the yard.  ISABELLE BARKS FRANTICALLY. When Graham reaches the porch stairs, he stops and turns. There is no one behind him.  The wall of crops fifty feet away sway in the gentle night breeze. Graham gains control of his breathing.  He turns and walk the screen door, slowing his breathing down with each ste

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham steps into the kitchen.  His hair is messed.  His shirt has a few leaves from corn stalks stuck to it.  He locks the back door. The children don't notice his presence.  They're splashin each other at the sink as they clean the dinner dishes. Graham looks through the kitchen doorway to the family ro He sees Merrill there. Merrill's hands are in his pockets as he stares at the WO BASEBALL BAT mounted above the fireplace.  Merrill doesn' notice him either. Graham takes two steps to the kitchen table and slowly ta a seat.  His breathing is a slow controlled pant.  He run one shaky hand through his hair as he gathers himself and thinks.  His kind eyes stare down at the ground as he slo his mind.  Beat. Merrill is the first to notice him.  He moves from where baseball bat is hung, into the kitchen.  As he passes the children at the sink, he turns off the faucet. The children stop playing and look up to Merrill.  They follow his stare to the kitchen table. Beat.  Graham looks up at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) Okay. (beat) Let's turn on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- first appeared fifty two minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGED IN TWO "V'S" SIDE BY SIDE.
dialogues.text: Bo puts her finger to the screen and counts the hovering lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen. Morgan, Merrill and Graham stand silently before the television set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mexico City officials as well as U.S. officials have confirmed that these are not air crafts from either government's airforce.  The first sighting was made by an Air Mexico 747 en route from Mazatlan to New York as the unidentified crafts entered Mexico City air space.  They were not detected by radar by either country. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crazies were right. Beat.  Everyone just watches the fourteen lights hovering the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to tape this... Morgan reaches into the pile of video tapes under the television stand.  He grabs one. Bo snatches the video as Morgan tries to put it into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ballet recital. Morgan stares at his sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gravely serious) Listen Bo.  This is very important.  Everything people have written about in science books is going to change.  The history of the world's future is on the TV right now.  We need to record this so you can show your children this tape and say you were there... (beat) For your children Bo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ballet recital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! Graham doesn't take his eyes off the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preoccupied) Find another tape. Graham and Merrill sit down at the same time on the sofa. They both have the same dazed, slow movements. Morgan rummages through the pile of videos frantically. finds one and reaches for the VCR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Merrill, I'm using your tape. Morgan slams the tape marked "Bay Watch" into the VCR and presses record.  He's breathing heavy now.  Wheezing actually. Morgan moves to the sofa and takes a seat in between his father and his uncle.  Bo walks over and squeezes in also The four of them stare at the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You're seeing a live feed from our NBC affiliate down in Mexico City.  The time there is 7:17pm.  This image has not been adjusted or enhanced in any way.  What you're seeing is real. (beat) Everything they wrote in science books is about to change. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) Told you. Morgan brings his asthma spray to his mouth and inhales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family room lights are off now.  The TV is still on. SOUND IS MUTED.  There are a couple glasses of Bo's water the television now. The fourteen lights are still hovering on the screen.  Mo is asleep on Graham's lap.  Bo is asleep on Merrill's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Some people are probably thinking this is the end of the world. Graham turns his sleepy eyes away from the screen to Merr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) That's true. Merrill looks his brother in the eyes.  Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Do you think it's a possibility?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) How can you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) That wasn't the answer you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Can you at least pretend to be like you used to be?  Give me some comfort? Beat.  Graham thinks it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) ... There are all different ways you can tell that there's someone really there watching out for us.  You see signs.  Sometimes they're little ones.  You think of someone.  The phone rings.  They're on the phone... Sometimes they're big, like fourteen lights hovering over Mexico City. (beat) Sure, there are a lot of people watching this who think this could be a bad thing.  But there are a lot of people watching this, who think it's a miracle.  A sign of God's existence.  It's all in how you look at things Merrill. (beat) What you have to decide is what kind of person you are?  Are you the type who believes in miracles and looks for signs or are you the kind who believes, things just happen by chance? Beat.  Merrill is deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was at this party once.  I'm on a couch with Sara Mckinney.  She was just sitting there, looking beautiful and staring at me.  I go to lean in and kiss her and I realize I have gum in my mouth.  I turn and take out the gum.  Stuff it in my paper cup next to the sofa and turn around.  Sara Mckinney throws up all over herself. (beat) I knew the second it happened.  It was a miracle.  I could have been kissing her when she threw up.  That would have scarred me for life.  I may never have recovered. Merrill looks at the TV screen.  Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a miracle man.  Those lights are a miracle. Graham smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) There you go. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) So which type are you? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Do you feel comforted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) What does it matter then? The two of them turn back to the silent screen of the television.  It's a long beat before Graham speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Do you know what Colleen's last words were before they killed her? Beat.  Merrill turns and stares quietly at his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) She said, "See", and then her eyes glazed a bit and she said... "Tell Merrill to swing away." Merrill's mouth opens a bit.  Graham turns and chuckles a his expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Do you know why she said that? Merrill nods, "No."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Because the nerve endings in her brain were firing as she died, and some random memory of us at one of your baseball games popped into her head. (beat) There is no one watching out for us Merrill.  We're all on our own. Graham turns back to the television.  Beat.
